facts.text: Two questions were referred to the High Court of Judicature of Assam and Nagaland by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Calcutta Bench under section 66(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

anchor.surface_text: Sikri, J. Two questions were referred to the High Court of Judicature of Assam and Nagaland, under section 66 2  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Calcutta Bench A

facts.text: The respondent Jwalaprasad Agarwala was a partner in Messrs. Onkarmal Jwalaprasad

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, Jwalaprasad Agarwala, hereinafter referred to as the assessee, was a partner in Messrs. Onkarmal Jwalaprasad.

facts.text: Assessee divided the balance of his capital account as partner in the books of that firm in four equal parts and made a gift of Rs. 74,721 to each of his four minor sons in July, 1953

anchor.surface_text: He divided the balance of his capital account as partner in the books of that firm in four equal parts and made a gift of a sum of Rs. 74,721 to each of his four minor sons in July, 1953.

facts.text: During the accounting year relevant to assessment year 1959-60, three of his sons had attained majority and the fourth son, Parmeshwar Agarwala, was still a minor

anchor.surface_text: During the accounting year relevant to assessment year 1959-60, three of his sons had attained majoprity and the fourth son, Parmeshwar Agarwala, was still a monor.

facts.text: Parmeshwar Agarwala has been admitted to the benefits of the partnership in the three firms: 1. Jwalaprasad Mulchand, Dhubri, Assam (Dhubri firm), 2. Jwalaprasad Mulchand Galla Dept. Dhubri Assam (Galla firm), 3. Jwalaprasad Mulchand, Calcutta (Calcutta firm)

anchor.surface_text: Parmeshwar Agarwala has been admitted to the benefits of the partnership in the three firms  1  Jwalaprasad Mulchand, Dhubri,  Assam  - hereinafter referred to as the Dhubri firm,  2  Jwalaprasad Mulchand  Galla Dept.  Dhubri  Assam  - hereinafter

facts.text: The sum of Rs. 74,721 gifted to the minor was invested in the Dhubri firm

anchor.surface_text: The sum of Rs. 74,721 gifted to the minor was invested in the Dhubri firm.

facts.text: Apparently the partnership deed did not make it a condition precedent that the partners should contribute any capital although it was provided that the partners could lend money to the firm and would be entitled to interest at 4 1/2%

anchor.surface_text: Apparently the partnership deed did number make it a companydition precedent that that the partners should companytribute any capital although it was provided that the partners companyld lend money to the firm and would be entitled to interest at 4 1/2.

facts.text: These three firms made a profit during the relevant year and the minors share came to Rs. 22,476

anchor.surface_text: These three firms made a profit during the relevant year and the minors share came to Rs. 22,476.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer included this sum in the income of the assessee for the assessment year 1959-60

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer included this sum in the income of the assessee for the assessment year 1959-60.

facts.text: The assessee appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner

anchor.surface_text: The assessee appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and companytended

facts.text: Assessee contended before AAC that only the interest on the original gift money and not the entire credit balance of Parmeshwar Agarwala with the firms should have been included in the appellants assessment under section 16(3)(a)(iv)

anchor.surface_text: that only the interest on the original gift money and number the entire credit balance of Parmeshwar Agarwala with the firms should have been included in the appellants assessment under section 16 3  a  iv

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected the first contention of assessee

facts.text: The assessee appealed to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: The assessee appealed to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal noticed that some time during the previous year for 1957-58 assessment year a sum of Rs 11,000 out of the personal account of Parameshwar Agarwala in the books of the Dhubri firm had been transferred to the Calcutta firm

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal numbericed that some time during the previous year for 1957-58 assessment year a sum of Rs 11,000 out of the personal account of Parameshwar Agarwala, as appearing in the books of the Dhubri firm had been transfered to the Calcutta firm,

facts.text: No capital seems to have been invested in the name of the minor in the Galla firm

anchor.surface_text: and that numbercapital seems to have been invested in the name of the minor in the Galla firm.

facts.text: Tribunal held that the share incomes from the three firms is liable to be included in the assessment of the father under section 16(3)(a)(iv)

anchor.surface_text: Thus, in spite of the fact that each of these firms are paying interest to the minor, we are obliged to hold that the share incomes which the minoe had bee deriving from each of these firms is directly attributable to the introduction of the original capital of Rs. 74,721

facts.text: The Tribunal excluded the interest on the other accretions to the capital account of the minor from the assessment of the appellant

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, however,excluded the interest on the other accretions to the capital account of the minor as appearing in the three firms accounts from the assessment of the appellant.

facts.text: The High Court on a reference answered the questions in favour of the assessee

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, on a reference, answered the questions in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: The Commissioner of Income-tax obtained special leave from this court and the appeal is now before us

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax obtained special leave from this companyrt and the appeal is number before us.

facts.text: High Court held that the minors share of profit in Galla and Calcutta firms is not liable to be included under section 16(3)(a)(iv) as there was no contribution of any sum by the minor son out of the gift money

anchor.surface_text: The High Court first dealt with the income of the minor form the Galla firm and the Calcutta firm. The High Court held that merely because the minor was admitted to the benefits of these two firms and as there must be some sort of financial companynection between the three firms, it cannot be said some sort financial companynection between the three firms, it cannot be said that the minors sharte of profit in these two firms is the benefit directly arising or indirectly arising to the minor from the assets transferred by the assessee to him.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with High Court finding on Galla and Calcutta firms

anchor.surface_text: We agree with this finding.

facts.text: High Court held for Dhubri firm that there is no evidence that the minor was admitted only because of introduction of initial capital of Rs.74,721

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court that there is numberevidence on record to justify a finding that the minor had been admitted as a partner in the firm, Jwalaprasad Mulchand, Dhubri, only because of the introduction of the initial capital of Rs. 74,721 in his name by his father, the assessee.

facts.text: From the account books it appears that Rs. 74,721 were taken as the minors deposit and the minor was admitted to the benefits of the partnership

anchor.surface_text: The High Court observed that from the account books it appears that Rs. 74,721 were taken as the minors deposit in the account books and , further, that the minor was admitted to the benefits of the partnership.

facts.text: There is no evidence to show that he was admitted to partnership on account of the sum of Rs.74,721 given by father

anchor.surface_text: There is numberevidence to show that he was admitted to sum of Rs. 74,721 given to him by his father in the firm.
